types.name: ID
types.description:
The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to
refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON
response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable.
When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer
(such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: ActionMonitorActionIdType
types.description: The Type of Identifier used to fetch a single resource. Default is ID.

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

fields.name: public
fields.description: Whether a content type is intended for use publicly either via the admin interface or by front-end users. While the default settings of exclude_from_search, publicly_queryable, show_ui, and show_in_nav_menus are inherited from public, each does not rely on this relationship and controls a very specific intention.

fields.name: showInMenu
fields.description: Where to show the content type in the admin menu. To work, $show_ui must be true. If true, the post type is shown in its own top level menu. If false, no menu is shown. If a string of an existing top level menu (eg. "tools.php" or "edit.php?post_type=page"), the post type will be placed as a sub-menu of that.

fields.name: showInNavMenus
fields.description: Makes this content type available for selection in navigation menus.

fields.name: showInRest
fields.description: Whether the content type is associated with a route under the the REST API "wp/v2" namespace.

fields.name: showUi
fields.description: Whether to generate and allow a UI for managing this content type in the admin.

types.name: String
types.description:
The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8
character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to
represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: Int
types.description:
The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric
values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

Accepts '404' (return a 404 instead of a default image), 'retro' (8bit), 'monsterid' (monster), 'wavatar' (cartoon face), 'indenticon' (the 'quilt'), 'mystery', 'mm', or 'mysteryman' (The Oyster Man), 'blank' (transparent GIF), or 'gravatar_default' (the Gravatar logo).

fields.name: extraAttr
fields.description: HTML attributes to insert in the IMG element. Is not sanitized.

fields.name: forceDefault
fields.description: Whether to always show the default image, never the Gravatar.

fields.name: foundAvatar
fields.description: Whether the avatar was successfully found.

fields.name: height
fields.description: Height of the avatar image.

fields.name: isRestricted
fields.description: Whether the object is restricted from the current viewer

fields.name: rating
fields.description: What rating to display avatars up to. Accepts 'G', 'PG', 'R', 'X', and are judged in that order.

fields.name: scheme
fields.description: Type of url scheme to use. Typically HTTP vs. HTTPS.

fields.name: size
fields.description: The size of the avatar in pixels. A value of 96 will match a 96px x 96px gravatar image.

fields.name: url
fields.description: URL for the gravatar image source.

fields.name: width
fields.description: Width of the avatar image.

types.name: Theme

fields.name: author
fields.description: Name of the theme author(s), could also be a company name. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "Author" ).

fields.name: authorUri
fields.description: URI for the author/company website. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "AuthorURI" ).

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the theme. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "Description" ).

fields.name: id
fields.description: The globally unique identifier of the theme object.

fields.name: isRestricted
fields.description: Whether the object is restricted from the current viewer

fields.name: name
fields.description: Display name of the theme. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "Name" ).

fields.name: screenshot
fields.description: The URL of the screenshot for the theme. The screenshot is intended to give an overview of what the theme looks like. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get_screenshot().

fields.name: slug
fields.description: The theme slug is used to internally match themes. Theme slugs can have subdirectories like: my-theme/sub-theme. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get_stylesheet().

fields.name: tags
fields.description: URI for the author/company website. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "Tags" ).

fields.name: themeUri
fields.description: A URI if the theme has a website associated with it. The Theme URI is handy for directing users to a theme site for support etc. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "ThemeURI" ).

fields.name: version
fields.description: The current version of the theme. This field is equivalent to WP_Theme->get( "Version" ).

types.name: PostCategoriesNodeInput
types.description: List of categories to connect the post to. If an ID is set, it will be used to create the connection. If not, it will look for a slug. If neither are valid existing terms, and the site is configured to allow terms to be created during post mutations, a term will be created using the Name if it exists in the input, then fallback to the slug if it exists.

If neither are valid existing terms, and the site is configured to allow terms to be created during post mutations, a term will be created using the Name if it exists in the input, then fallback to the slug if it exists.

types.name: PostTagsNodeInput
types.description: List of tags to connect the post to. If an ID is set, it will be used to create the connection. If not, it will look for a slug. If neither are valid existing terms, and the site is configured to allow terms to be created during post mutations, a term will be created using the Name if it exists in the input, then fallback to the slug if it exists.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.
